questions.question: Which of these are most important for an organism to maintain homeostasis?

choices.answer: behaviors & negative feedback
reproduction & development
interactions with nonliving things
dependence on other organisms

questions.question: The long-term effects of a disruption of homeostasis include __.

choices.answer: establishment of feedback mechanisms
regulation of the internal environment
the immune system's taking control
destruction of organ systems

questions.question: How do stomata function in most plants relative to gas exchange?

choices.answer: Stomata close to prevent nitrogen from escaping.
Stomata close to allow photosynthesis to occur.
Stomata open to allow CO<sub>2 </sub>in and O<sub>2</sub> and water out.
Stomata open to allow water to build up in the plant.

questions.question: What is the role of a receptor in helping an organism maintain homeostasis?

choices.answer: receives messages sent by the control center
compares current conditions with ideal values for those conditions
detects stimuli & sends info to the control center
carries out a response to restore internal conditions

questions.question: When you need more oxygen, how does the circulatory system respond?

choices.answer: More blood is sent to the lungs & less to the rest of the body.
Blood vessels to the arms & legs constrict to conserve oxygen.
Heart beats at a faster rate to match the rise in breathing.
Blood moves more slowly through organs to carry away more waste.

questions.question: How does the liver help to regulate glucose levels in the blood?

choices.answer: by releasing glucagon
by storing glucose
by excreting excess water
by producing insulin

questions.question: Internal control systems maintain homeostasis by regulating which of these?

choices.answer: external conditions
pH of body fluids
the body's control centers
receptors in the body

questions.question: What would happen on a hot day if your brain did not receive input that your body was starting to heat up?

choices.answer: You would start to overheat.
You would start to sweat.
You would start to shiver.
You would not feel any effect at all.

questions.question: Which of these is an example of positive feedback loop?

choices.answer: release of glucose by the liver in response to low blood sugar
plants closing their stomata in response to water loss
platelets stimulating the activation of more platelets during clotting
removal of salt from a saltwater fish during osmoregulation

questions.question: The body's internal environment must stay __.

choices.answer: exactly the same at all times
the same as its external environment
within narrow ranges that support human life
away from sudden outside temperature changes

questions.question: Flatworms are invertebrates with soft bodies & some live in freshwater. How might this organism handle osmoregulation?

choices.answer: excretes dilute urine
excretes concentrated urine
absorbs as much salt as possible from its surroundings
excretes as much as as possible from its body

questions.question: The body works to maintain homeostasis in response to what conditions?

choices.answer: internal & external changes
tissue & cell formation
cell differentiation & determination
production of key vitamins

questions.question: On a hot day, which of these is an outward sign that thermoregulation is taking place?

choices.answer: dry mouth
sunburn
slow breathing
sweating

questions.question: Which of these does homeostasis most directly related?

choices.answer: interacting systems
scale & structure
stability
evolution

questions.question: Why are insulin & glucagon feedback loops examples of negative feedback loops?

choices.answer: The stimulus was a lower level of blood glucose.
The stimulus caused the insulin to take on a negative charge.
The effector caused a response in the opposite direction as the stimulus.
The effector caused a response in the same direction as the stimulus.

questions.question: Having numerous alveoli in the lungs creates more surface area. What is a benefit of this?

choices.answer: It allows the blood to move more quickly.
It allows diffusion to occur more quickly.
It allows the lungs to expand more slowly.
It keeps gases from getting into the blood too quickly.

questions.question: What is the relationship between blood sugar, insulin, & glucagon levels in the blood stream? (2 answers)

choices.answer: Glucose is directly related to insulin.
Glucose is inversely related to insulin.
Insulin is directly related to glucagon.
Insulin is inversely related to glucagon.

questions.question: The maintenance of water homeostasis in a plant is the result of a __ feedback loop.

choices.answer: negative
positive

questions.question: Is thermoregulation an example of negative or positive feedback?

choices.answer: Negative, it moves the temperature away from the set point.
Negative, it moves the temperature back toward the set point.
Positive, it moves the temperature away from the set point.
Positive, it moves the temperature back toward the set point.

questions.question: Saltwater fish swims where the salt concentration is lower than normal. Which will not restore homeostasis?

choices.answer: decrease water intake
increase water intake
decrease salt excretion
increase water excretion
